supply_logistics.supply_status: Strained - Division advanced 105km into Egypt during invasion (9-16 September 1940), establishing defensive positions at Halfaya Pass. Supply lines extended from Bardia/Tobruk bases across border. Fuel reserves reduced to 12 days due to invasion movements, ammunition 18 days for defensive operations, water critical at 2.5L/man/day in desert heat. Motor transport worn by desert operations and skirmishing at Fort Capuzzo (June-July). Animal transport essential for rough terrain near escarpment.

weather_environment.season_quarter: 1940-Q3 (July-September) - High summer in Egypt/Libya border region
weather_environment.terrain_type: Desert escarpment and coastal plain - Halfaya Pass, Sofafi region. Rocky, extremely arid, no natural water sources.

subordinate_units.composition: 2 field artillery groups (8 batteries), 1 AT company, 1 AA company

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 62° Sezione Sussistenza e Sezione Trasporti Motorizzati

tactical_doctrine.role: Right flank security and defensive operations during Italian invasion of Egypt
special_capabilities: Autotrasportabile organization - partial motorization for desert mobility
Adapted for desert operations with animal transport backup
Extensive use of mule transport for escarpment terrain
Experienced in border warfare from Fort Capuzzo skirmishes (June-July 1940)
known_issues: Insufficient motorization - only enough trucks to move portion of division at once
Obsolete artillery (WWI-era Austrian guns refurbished in 1933)
Binary (two-regiment) structure left division undermanned compared to three-regiment divisions
Vehicle wear from desert operations reduced operational readiness
Extended supply lines after invasion increased logistical strain
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Mixed motor and animal transport system proved essential during invasion. Mule train enabled operations along escarpment terrain at Halfaya Pass and Sofafi region.

scenario_suitability: Italian invasion of Egypt (9-16 September 1940) - PRIMARY
wargaming_data.experience_level: Regular - Combat experienced from border skirmishes
special_rules: Mixed transport: Can operate with reduced mobility when vehicles unavailable
Desert-adapted: No penalty for desert terrain
Weak AT defense: -1 modifier vs armor
Metropolitan division: Higher morale than colonial units
Combat experienced: +1 to initiative from Fort Capuzzo operations
historical_engagements: Skirmishes at Fort Capuzzo (14 June - 23 July 1940)
Italian invasion of Egypt (9-16 September 1940) - covered Tenth Army right flank, advanced through Halfaya Pass
Battle of Marmarica (11 December 1940) - positions at Sidi Omar untenable
Battle of Bardia (3-5 January 1941) - division destroyed

historical_notes.status_1940_q3: Combat operational. Division participated in Italian invasion of Egypt (9-16 September 1940), advancing from Sidi Omar, pushing past British harassing parties to converge on Halfaya Pass. On 13 September passed through Halfaya and was ordered to halt and prepare defensive positions. Held escarpment positions from Sofafi to Halfaya covering 10th Army right (inland) flank. Prior combat experience from Fort Capuzzo skirmishes (June-July 1940). Motor transport worn from desert operations, supply lines extended across border.
historical_notes.combat_record: Division saw continuous action in Q3 1940. Skirmished with British forces at Fort Capuzzo from 14 June to 23 July. Participated in invasion of Egypt starting 9 September, covering Tenth Army's inland flank during 105km advance to Sidi Barrani region. Advanced through Halfaya Pass on 13 September and established defensive positions along escarpment from Sofafi to Halfaya. Later destroyed at Bardia on 5 January 1941 during British Operation Compass.
historical_notes.notable_features: Named after the ancient name for the surrounding region of Libya. Originally all three regiments (115th, 116th, 44th) were renamed 'Marmarica' in 1939 though they retained their original 'Treviso' designations in official records. Metropolitan division permanently stationed in Libya from formation. First combat experience in border warfare prepared division for invasion operations.
historical_notes.fate: Destroyed during Battle of Bardia, 5 January 1941. Not reformed.
